action.action-desc: Ms. DelBene (for herself, Mr. Cicilline, Mr. Cohen, and Mr. Smith of Washington) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on the Judiciary, and in addition to the Committee on Energy and Commerce, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To make the Controlled Substances Act inapplicable with respect to marihuana in States that have legalized marijuana and have in effect a statewide regulatory regime to protect certain Federal interests, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the State Marihuana And Regulatory Tolerance Enforcement Act.

section.header: Inapplicability of Controlled Substances Act to marihuana in certain States

subsection.text: Part E of the Controlled Substances Act (21 U.S.C. 871 et seq.) is amended by adding at the end the following:

section.header: Inapplicability to marihuana in certain States

subsection.text: For the period described in subsection (b), this title shall not apply with respect to the production, manufacture, distribution, prescribing, dispensing, possession, and use of marihuana in a State if each of the following conditions is met:

paragraph.text: The State submits a request to the Attorney General certifying that the State has legalized marihuana for recreational or medical use.

The request includes a certification that the State has, or will have, in effect a statewide regulatory regime for marihuana that is sufficient to protect Federal interests, including each of the following:

subparagraph.text: Preventing the distribution of marihuana to minors.
Preventing revenue from the sale of marihuana from going to criminal enterprises, gangs, and cartels.
Preventing the diversion of marihuana from States where the manufacture, distribution, dispensing, and possession of marihuana is legal to other States.
Preventing State-authorized marihuana activity from being used as a cover or pretext for the trafficking of other illegal drugs or other illegal activity.
Preventing violence and the use of firearms in the cultivation and distribution of marihuana.
Preventing drugged driving and the exacerbation of other adverse public health consequences associated with marihuana use.
Preventing the growing of marihuana on public lands and the attendant public safety and environmental dangers posed by marihuana production on public lands.
Preventing marihuana possession or use on Federal property.

paragraph.text: The State agrees to study and report annually to the Attorney General regarding outcomes of legalizing marihuana in the State on the following:

subparagraph.text: Prevalence of drug-related organized crime activity.

subsection.text: Subject to subsection (c), the period described in this subsection is, with respect to a State—

paragraph.text: the period of 3 years beginning on the date of receipt by the Attorney General of a request under subsection (a)(1); and
any subsequent, consecutive 3-year period if, by the beginning of such period, the State submits a request under subsection (a)(1) for such period.

subsection.text: The effective period of a request under subsection (a)(1) shall commence not sooner than the effective date of the State’s regulatory regime required by subsection (a)(2).

subparagraph.text: continually review the production, manufacture, distribution, prescribing, dispensing, possession, and use of marihuana in a State with a waiver in effect under subsection (a); and

after providing notice and an opportunity to correct under paragraph (2), revoke such waiver if the Attorney General finds, with respect to such State, that the conditions listed in subsection (a) are no longer met.

paragraph.text: If the Attorney General finds that the conditions listed in subsection (a) are no longer met, the Attorney General shall give the State involved—

subparagraph.text: a period of not less than 180 days to correct any failure to meet the conditions listed in subsection (a).

subsection.text: Nothing in this section shall be construed to prohibit the Federal Government from providing assistance to a State (under Federal law other than this title) in the implementation or enforcement of State law relating to the production, manufacture, distribution, prescribing, dispensing, possession, or use of marihuana.
In this section, the term tainted means containing microbes, pesticides, or controlled substances other than marihuana.

The table of contents at the beginning of the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970 (Public Law 91–513) is amended by inserting at the end of the items relating to part E of title II the following new item:

toc.toc-entry: Sec. 521. Inapplicability to marihuana in certain States.
